citation.article-title: Polaribacter gen. nov., with three new species, P. irgensii sp. nov., P. franzmannii sp. nov. and P. filamentus sp. nov., gas vacuolate polar marine bacteria of the Cytophaga-Flavobacterium-Bacteroides group and reclassification of 'Flectobacillus glomeratus' as Polaribacter glomeratus comb. nov.

p.s: Description of Polaribacter franzmannii sp. nov.
Polaribacter franzmannii (franz.man'ni.i. franzmannii in honour of Peter D. Franzmann, Australian microbiologist and polar researcher)
Members of this species grow as large rods 0.8-1.6 μm in width and 4-16 μm in length.
Gas vesicles are present in these light to dark orange coloured cells, but sometimes sparingly depending on the growth medium.
Cells are capable of growth on glycerol and N-acetyl-β-glucosamine.
Acid is produced from growth on D-fructose, D-galactose, D-glucose, mannose, lactose, maltose, sucrose and trehalose.
Aesculin and gelatin are hydrolysed by this species.
Cells can grow from ≤4 to 10°C, but not at 15°C.
Principal fatty acids include 17% 15:0 iso-3-OH, 11% 15:1 iso-G (position of double bond unknown) and 9% each of 15:0 iso, 15:1ω6cis and 16:1ω7cis when grown on SWCm agar at 10 °C.
The G + C content as determined by thermal denaturation is 32±1 mol%.
Isolated from sea ice in McMurdo Sound, Antarctica.
The type strain of this species is strain 301 (= ATCC 700399).
